title: Woolworths underpayments could cost executives their bonuses
text:
Woolworths' estimated $200 million to $300 million wage bill tops a spate of multi-million dollar underpayments over the past year, including Wesfarmers' Bunnings, the Commonwealth Bank, the ABC and Michael Hill Jewellers.

Super Retail Group chief executive Peter Birtles exited his company earlier this year after uncovering $43 million in underpayments.

Fund managers said Woolworths shareholders would expect senior management to suffer a significant reduction in performance bonuses.

"It speaks to the complexity of the retail award but in an organisation this size with the resource they have it's completely unacceptable," said one fund manager, who declined to be named.

"I believe the board needs to take accountability and forfeit director fees, at a minimum, or lose their seats, as this is a clear failure of governance and oversight."

Experts have warned the underpayment of salaried staff is a "time bomb" for big corporates and the retail union has called for all retailers to start conducting audits.

So far, Woolworths has found 5,700 managers, on salaries averaging $73,000 a year, were underpaid by as much as $5,200 a year but the staff numbers are expected to climb substantially once the audit stretches back to 2010.

Fair Work Ombudsman Sandra Parker, who was not aware of the full underpayment until the market was told, said she was "not satisfied" with Woolworths' transparency and had launched an investigation to "hold them to account".

While the retailer's law firm Ashurst notified the FWO about compliance issues in August, it did not provide "any of the additional information that we expected, including information on quantum, dimension or nature of the breaches", she said.

"We expected it to be large by the fact that they wrote it with lawyers but we were shocked at the size of this underpayment... It's massive."

Mr Banducci said the company had only received the final underpayment estimates on Wednesday morning and disclosed them as soon as possible.

He said the company expected to make "a contrition payment", which are paid by businesses who enter undertakings with the regulator to avoid prosecution and usually amount to 2 per cent of the total underpayment.

'Time bomb ticking'

Woolworths started reviewing salaried staff in February with the assistance of PwC when a handful of managers questioned why they were paid less than union staff under the new enterprise agreement.

The company historically ensured salaries covered ordinary hours and reasonable overtime on an average roster but did not account for award penalties or allowances triggered from long hours or late nights.

The problem of underpaying salaried staff was also behind million dollar underpayments at George Calombaris' Made Establishment and defence giant Thales and the shoppies union said it was now "call[ing] on all retailers to audit their payroll settings especially for salary staff."

Deloitte partner and former FWO, Natalie James, said companies were "brazenly overconfident" about their compliance in the area, with many HR offices unaware the award still applied to those under annualised salaries.

"There is either a naivety or neglect in the way business has been approaching these annualised arrangements and it has resulted in long-standing underpayments," she said.

"If business isn't dusting off these arrangements right now they need to know they have a blatant time bomb ticking away in their payroll."

From March next year, new rules will require companies to conduct regular pay reconciliations for salaried employees under 19 industry awards, including administrative workers, graduate lawyers and restaurant staff.

FWO puts boards on notice

Ms Parker warned she was increasingly frustrated by the upsurge in underpayments from large businesses and "intended to take this issue up with boards around the country".

"Frankly that is the level within organisations that should be taking an active leadership role on this issue, and seeking assurance about compliance from executive managers."

Woolworths has promised to repay workers with interest and will provide an update in February and a final account in its full year results.
description: Woolworths CEO Brad Banducci said he expects to lose his bonus and flagged further consequences over what is the biggest underpayment on record.
